DOC.HEAD: White House Press Office Closes For Holiday
DOC.TEXT: Despite the U.S. fighting in Panama, the White House and State Department closed their press offices Friday night for a long holiday weekend, not to reopen until the Tuesday after Christmas. ``Any details on the military situation on the ground will come from the Defense Department,'' said presidential spokesman Marlin Fitzwater. The Pentagon planned to keep its press office open on Saturday. After that, the Pentagon planned to follow the State Department and White House in the practice of having a press duty officer available by telephone. ``We do not expect to release any new information here unless there's a dramatic turn in events,'' Fitzwater said at his briefing. Of course, the most dramatic event would be the capture or death of deposed Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega, the target of a U.S. manhunt in Panama. Defense Secretary Dick Cheney and Secretary of State James A. Baker III were booked for appearances Sunday on network talk shows. The State Department's Panama task force was to remain staffed around the clock. Cheney cancelled a holiday trip to Wyoming and other plans to remain in Washington to monitor the battle for Panama. President Bush, meanwhile, settled in at Camp David in Maryland's Catoctin Mountains for a five-day stay. He was to receive regular updates and daily briefings from Brent Scowcroft, his national security adviser, as well as Cheney and Baker. Bush will remain at his presidential retreat until he departs Wednesday for a vacation trip to Texas, returning to Washington on New Year's Day.
